Throughout the history of the [Grammy Awards](/wiki/Grammy_award "Grammy
award"), many significant records have been set. This page only includes the
competitive awards which have been won by various artists. This does not
include the various special awards that are presented by the [National Academy
of Recording Arts and
Sciences](/wiki/National_Academy_of_Recording_Arts_and_Sciences "National
Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences") such as Lifetime Achievement Awards,
Trustees Awards, Technical Awards or Legend Awards. The page however does
include other non-performance related Grammys (known as the Craft & Production
Fields) that may have been presented to the artist(s).

All the records are as of the [2017 Grammy Awards](/wiki/2017_Grammy_Awards
"2017 Grammy Awards").

### Most Grammys
won[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Most Grammys won")]

The record for the most Grammy Awards won in a lifetime is held by Sir Georg
Solti, a Hungarian-British conductor who conducted the [Chicago Symphony
Orchestra](/wiki/Chicago_Symphony_Orchestra "Chicago Symphony Orchestra") for
twenty-two years. He has won a total of 31 competitive Grammy Awards out of 74
nominations and was awarded a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award in 1996.[1][2]

---|---|---

2 | [Quincy Jones](/wiki/Quincy_Jones "Quincy Jones") | 27  
[Alison Krauss](/wiki/Alison_Krauss "Alison Krauss")  
4 | [Pierre Boulez](/wiki/Pierre_Boulez "Pierre Boulez") | 26

[Stevie Wonder](/wiki/Stevie_Wonder "Stevie Wonder")

### Most Grammys won by an engineer or
mixer[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Most Grammys won by an engineer or mixer")]

[Al Schmitt](/wiki/Al_Schmitt "Al Schmitt"), with 20 awards, has won more
Grammy Awards than any other engineer or mixer.

### Youngest
winners[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Youngest winners")]

[The Peasall Sisters](/wiki/The_Peasall_Sisters "The Peasall Sisters") are the
youngest Grammy winners, when they were credited artists on the [_O Brother,
Where Art Thou?_ soundtrack](/wiki/O_Brother,_Where_Art_Thou%3F_\(soundtrack\)
"O Brother, Where Art Thou? \(soundtrack\)"), which won Album of the Year in
2002.[4] LeAnn Rimes is the youngest individual winner. She was 14 years old
when she won her first two awards in 1997. She was also the first
[Country](/wiki/Country_music "Country music") artist to win the Best New
Artist Grammy.

Rank | Age | Artist  
---|---|---  
1 | 7 years | Leah Peasall  
2 | 9 years | Hannah Peasall  
3 | 13 years | Sarah Peasall  
4 | 14 years, 182 days | [LeAnn Rimes](/wiki/LeAnn_Rimes "LeAnn Rimes")  
5 | 14 years, 313 days | [Luis Miguel](/wiki/Luis_Miguel "Luis Miguel")  
6 | 17 years, 81 days | [Lorde](/wiki/Lorde "Lorde")  
7 | 18 years, 105 days | [Daya](/wiki/Daya_\(singer\) "Daya \(singer\)")  
8 | 18 years, 123 days | [Monica](/wiki/Monica_\(entertainer\) "Monica \(entertainer\)")  
9 | 19 years, 67 days | [Christina Aguilera](/wiki/Christina_Aguilera "Christina Aguilera")  
10 | 19 years, 112 days | [LaTavia Roberson](/wiki/LaTavia_Roberson "LaTavia Roberson")

### Eldest
winners[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Eldest winners")]

Pinetop Perkins is the eldest person to win a Grammy. In 2011 he was awarded
[Best Traditional Blues Album](/wiki/Best_Traditional_Blues_Album "Best
Traditional Blues Album") for _Joined At The Hip_ at 97 years of age.

Rank | Age | Artist  
---|---|---  
1 | 97 years, 221 days | [Pinetop Perkins](/wiki/Pinetop_Perkins "Pinetop Perkins")  
2 | 95 years, 31 days | [George Burns](/wiki/George_Burns "George Burns")  
3 | 91 years, 137 days | [Jimmy Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy Carter")  
4 | 90 years, 52 days | [Elizabeth Cotten](/wiki/Elizabeth_Cotten "Elizabeth Cotten")  
5 | 90 years, 26 days | [Betty White](/wiki/Betty_White "Betty White")  
  
**Note** : Sources vary on the birth year of Elizabeth Cotten, with some
stating it as 1893, while others say 1895. The above information credits it as
1895. With either year, Cotten is the oldest female Grammy winner.

### Most Album of the Year
wins[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Most Album of the Year wins")]

The record for most Album of the Year wins is three. Three recording artists,
four record producers, two mastering engineers and one engineer/mixer have won
the award three times.

  * [Frank Sinatra](/wiki/Frank_Sinatra "Frank Sinatra"), artist — _[Come Dance with Me!](/wiki/Come_Dance_with_Me!_\(album\) "Come Dance with Me! \(album\)")_ ([1960](/wiki/2nd_Annual_Grammy_Awards "2nd Annual Grammy Awards")), _[September of My Years](/wiki/September_of_My_Years "September of My Years")_ ([1966](/wiki/8th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "8th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[A Man and His Music](/wiki/A_Man_and_His_Music "A Man and His Music")_ ([1967](/wiki/9th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "9th Annual Grammy Awards"))
  * [Stevie Wonder](/wiki/Stevie_Wonder "Stevie Wonder"), artist — _[Innervisions](/wiki/Innervisions "Innervisions")_ ([1974](/wiki/16th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "16th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[Fulfillingness' First Finale](/wiki/Fulfillingness%27_First_Finale "Fulfillingness' First Finale")_ ([1975](/wiki/17th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "17th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[Songs in the Key of Life](/wiki/Songs_in_the_Key_of_Life "Songs in the Key of Life")_ ([1977](/wiki/19th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "19th Annual Grammy Awards"))
  * [Paul Simon](/wiki/Paul_Simon "Paul Simon"), artist — _[Bridge over Troubled Water](/wiki/Bridge_over_Troubled_Water "Bridge over Troubled Water")_ ([1971](/wiki/13th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "13th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[Still Crazy After All These Years](/wiki/Still_Crazy_After_All_These_Years "Still Crazy After All These Years")_ ([1976](/wiki/18th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "18th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[Graceland](/wiki/Graceland_\(album\) "Graceland \(album\)")_ ([1987](/wiki/29th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "29th Annual Grammy Awards"))
  * [David Foster](/wiki/David_Foster "David Foster"), producer — _[Unforgettable… with Love](/wiki/Unforgettable%E2%80%A6_with_Love "Unforgettable… with Love")_ ([1992](/wiki/34th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "34th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[The Bodyguard: Original Soundtrack Album](/wiki/The_Bodyguard:_Original_Soundtrack_Album "The Bodyguard: Original Soundtrack Album")_ ([1994](/wiki/36th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "36th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[Falling into You](/wiki/Falling_into_You "Falling into You")_ ([1997](/wiki/39th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "39th Annual Grammy Awards"))
  * [Phil Ramone](/wiki/Phil_Ramone "Phil Ramone"), producer — _[Still Crazy After All These Years](/wiki/Still_Crazy_After_All_These_Years "Still Crazy After All These Years")_ ([1976](/wiki/18th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "18th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[52nd Street](/wiki/52nd_Street_\(album\) "52nd Street \(album\)")_ ([1980](/wiki/22nd_Annual_Grammy_Awards "22nd Annual Grammy Awards")), _[Genius Loves Company](/wiki/Genius_Loves_Company "Genius Loves Company")_ ([2005](/wiki/47th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "47th Annual Grammy Awards"))
  * [Daniel Lanois](/wiki/Daniel_Lanois "Daniel Lanois"), producer — _[The Joshua Tree](/wiki/The_Joshua_Tree "The Joshua Tree")_ ([1988](/wiki/30th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "30th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[Time Out of Mind](/wiki/Time_Out_of_Mind_\(album\) "Time Out of Mind \(album\)")_ ([1998](/wiki/40th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "40th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb](/wiki/How_to_Dismantle_an_Atomic_Bomb "How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb")_ ([2006](/wiki/48th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "48th Annual Grammy Awards"))
  * [Bob Ludwig](/wiki/Bob_Ludwig "Bob Ludwig"), mastering engineer — _[Babel](/wiki/Babel_\(album\) "Babel \(album\)")_ ([2013](/wiki/55th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "55th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[Random Access Memories](/wiki/Random_Access_Memories "Random Access Memories")_ ([2014](/wiki/56th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "56th Annual Grammy Awards")), _[Morning Phase](/wiki/Morning_Phase "Morning Phase")_ ([2015](/wiki/57th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "57th Annual Grammy Awards"))

### Most Record of the Year
wins[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Most Record of the Year wins")]

The record for most wins, three each, is shared by:

  * [Paul Simon](/wiki/Paul_Simon "Paul Simon"), artist
  * [Tom Elmhirst](/wiki/Tom_Elmhirst "Tom Elmhirst"), engineer/mixer
  * [Tom Coyne](/wiki/Tom_Coyne_\(music_engineer\) "Tom Coyne \(music engineer\)"), mastering engineer

### Most Grammys won for consecutive
albums[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Most Grammys won for consecutive albums")]

[Pat Metheny](/wiki/Pat_Metheny "Pat Metheny") and his band the [Pat Metheny
Group](/wiki/Pat_Metheny_Group "Pat Metheny Group") have won 20 Grammy Awards
in total, including seven consecutive awards for seven consecutive albums.[5]
Metheny held the record for Grammy wins in the most different categories as of
the 2005 Grammy Awards:

  * [Best Jazz Fusion Performance](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Jazz_Fusion_Performance "Grammy Award for Best Jazz Fusion Performance") (1983, 1984, 1985, 1988, 1990)
  * [Best Instrumental Composition](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Instrumental_Composition "Grammy Award for Best Instrumental Composition") (1991)
  * [Best Contemporary Jazz Performance/Album](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Contemporary_Jazz_Album "Grammy Award for Best Contemporary Jazz Album") (1993, 1994, 1996, 1999, 2003, 2005)
  * [Best Jazz Instrumental Performance, Individual or Group](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Jazz_Instrumental_Album,_Individual_or_Group "Grammy Award for Best Jazz Instrumental Album, Individual or Group") (1998, 2000, 2013)
  * [Best Rock Instrumental Performance](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Rock_Instrumental_Performance "Grammy Award for Best Rock Instrumental Performance") (1999)
  * [Best Jazz Instrumental Solo](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Jazz_Instrumental_Solo "Grammy Award for Best Jazz Instrumental Solo") (2001)
  * [Best New Age Album](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_New_Age_Album "Grammy Award for Best New Age Album") (2004, 2012)

### Most consecutive Grammys won for the same
category[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Most consecutive Grammys won for the same category")]

Aretha Franklin holds the record for winning the most consecutive Grammys in
the same category. She won the [Grammy Award for Best Female R&B Vocal
Performance](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Female_R%26B_Vocal_Performance
"Grammy Award for Best Female R&B Vocal Performance") every year from 1968 to
1975, for an eight-year winning streak. She also won in this category in 1982,
1986, and 1988, giving her 11 wins in the category.

After Franklin, [Jimmy Sturr](/wiki/Jimmy_Sturr "Jimmy Sturr"), [Bill
Cosby](/wiki/Bill_Cosby "Bill Cosby") and [John Williams](/wiki/John_Williams
"John Williams") are tied for second place for consecutive Grammy wins in the
same category:

Sturr won six years in a row between 1987 and 1992 for [Best Polka
Album](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Polka_Album "Grammy Award for Best Polka
Album"). He also won for three runs of four consecutive years (1996–1999,
2001–2004, and 2006–2009.) He won 18 out of the 24 Best Polka Album Grammys
that were awarded since that category was added in 1985. The award was
discontinued in 2009.

Cosby won six years in a row between 1965 and 1970 for [Grammy Award for Best
Comedy Album](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Comedy_Album "Grammy Award for Best
Comedy Album").

Williams won six years in a row between 1978 and 1983 for [Grammy Award for
Best Score Soundtrack for Visual
Media](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Score_Soundtrack_for_Visual_Media "Grammy
Award for Best Score Soundtrack for Visual Media").

[Lenny Kravitz](/wiki/Lenny_Kravitz "Lenny Kravitz") won the [Best Male Rock
Vocal Performance](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Male_Rock_Vocal_Performance
"Grammy Award for Best Male Rock Vocal Performance") award four years in a row
(1999, 2000, 2001, 2002).

### Artists who have won all four General Field
awards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Artists who have won all four General Field awards")]

There have been only two artists who have won all four General Field awards.
In 1981, [Christopher Cross](/wiki/Christopher_Cross "Christopher Cross") won
Record, Album and Song of the Year as well as Best New Artist.[6]
[Adele](/wiki/Adele "Adele") is the second artist to win all four, and the
first female to do so. In 2009, she won Best New Artist and in 2012 and 2017,
she won Record, Album and Song of the Year.

### Most Grammys won by a record producer in one

"Edit section: Most Grammys won by a record producer in one night")]

The record for most awards won by a producer in one night is five. [Rick
Rubin](/wiki/Rick_Rubin "Rick Rubin") won five awards in
[2007](/wiki/49th_Annual_Grammy_Awards "49th Annual Grammy Awards") including
Record of the Year, Album of the Year and Best Country Album for the [Dixie
Chicks](/wiki/Dixie_Chicks "Dixie Chicks"), Best Rock Album for the [Red Hot
Chili Peppers](/wiki/Red_Hot_Chili_Peppers "Red Hot Chili Peppers") as well as
Producer of the Year, Non Classical.

### Most Grammys won by an engineer or mixer in one
night[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Most Grammys won by an engineer or mixer in one night")]

The most Grammys won by an engineer or mixer in one night is six. At the [59th
Annual Grammy Awards](/wiki/Grammy_Awards_of_2017 "Grammy Awards of 2017") in
2017, [Tom Elmhirst](/wiki/Tom_Elmhirst "Tom Elmhirst") won Record of the
Year, Album of the Year, Best Pop Vocal Album, Best Engineered Album Non
Classical, Best Alternative Music Album and Best Rock Album for his work on
Adele's '25', David Bowie's 'Blackstar' and Cage The Elephant's 'Tell Me I'm
Pretty'.

### Artist who has won all four General Field Awards at a single
ceremony[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Artist who has won all four General Field Awards at a single
ceremony")]

[Christopher Cross](/wiki/Christopher_Cross "Christopher Cross") (1981)
received all four General Field awards in one night. Cross won the [Record of
the Year](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Record_of_the_Year "Grammy Award for Record
of the Year") ("[Sailing](/wiki/Sailing_\(Christopher_Cross_song\) "Sailing
\(Christopher Cross song\)")"), [Album of the
Year](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Album_of_the_Year "Grammy Award for Album of the
Year") ("[Christopher Cross](/wiki/Christopher_Cross_\(album\) "Christopher
Cross \(album\)")"), [Song of the
Year](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Song_of_the_Year "Grammy Award for Song of the
Year") ("[Sailing](/wiki/Sailing_\(Christopher_Cross_song\) "Sailing
\(Christopher Cross song\)")"), and [Best New
Artist](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_New_Artist "Grammy Award for Best New
Artist") Grammys in a single ceremony.[7]

"Edit section: Most Grammys won by an album in one night")]

The most awards awarded to an album in one night is nine. In 2000
[Santana](/wiki/Santana_\(band\) "Santana \(band\)")'s
_[Supernatural](/wiki/Supernatural_\(Santana_album\) "Supernatural \(Santana

[Ray Charles](/wiki/Ray_Charles "Ray Charles") holds the record for most
posthumous awards won in one night. He was awarded five Grammy Awards in 2005
including Album of the Year.

### Grammy nominations in the most
categories[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Grammy nominations in the most categories")]

Bob Dylan has been nominated in more categories than any other musician. He
has been nominated in 12 different categories. These were in
[folk](/wiki/Folk_music "Folk music"), [spoken word](/wiki/Spoken_word "Spoken
word"), [country](/wiki/Country_music "Country music"), general,
[gospel](/wiki/Gospel_music "Gospel music"), [historical](/wiki/Reissue
"Reissue"), [rock](/wiki/Rock_music "Rock music"), [music
video](/wiki/Music_video "Music video"), [visual media](/wiki/Visual_media
"Visual media"), [pop](/wiki/Pop_music "Pop music"), [american
roots](/wiki/American_roots_music "American roots music"), and
[traditional](/wiki/Traditional_pop_music "Traditional pop music"). He is
followed by [Sir Paul McCartney](/wiki/Sir_Paul_McCartney "Sir Paul
McCartney") who has received nominations in the general field,
[pop](/wiki/Pop_music "Pop music"), [arrangement](/wiki/Arrangement
"Arrangement"), [rock](/wiki/Rock_music "Rock music"), [visual
media](/wiki/Visual_media "Visual media"), [music video](/wiki/Music_video
"Music video"), [spoken word](/wiki/Spoken_word "Spoken word"),
[historical](/wiki/Reissue "Reissue"), [alternative
music](/wiki/Alternative_music "Alternative music") and [rap](/wiki/Rap_music
"Rap music"). [Béla Fleck](/wiki/B%C3%A9la_Fleck "Béla Fleck") is the artist
with the third most nominations among categories. He has been nominated in the
[country](/wiki/Country_music "Country music"), [pop](/wiki/Pop_music "Pop
music"), [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz"), [bluegrass](/wiki/Bluegrass_music
"Bluegrass music"), [world music](/wiki/World_music "World music"),
[classical](/wiki/Classical_music "Classical music"), [folk](/wiki/Folk_music
"Folk music"), and [spoken word](/wiki/Spoken_word "Spoken word"), as well as
[composition](/wiki/Musical_composition "Musical composition") and
[arranging](/wiki/Arrangement "Arrangement") categories.

[Jack White](/wiki/Jack_White "Jack White") is the artist with the fourth most
nominations among categories. He has been nominated in the rock, general
field, alternative, country, pop, package, music video, american roots and
production, non-classical categories.

[Mark Knopfler](/wiki/Mark_Knopfler "Mark Knopfler") is the artist with the
fifth most nominations among categories. Knopfler has been nominated in the
rock, general field, country, music video, music for visual media, surround
sound, american roots and production, non-classical categories.

### Youngest
nominees[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Grammy_Award_records&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Youngest nominees")]

Leah Peasall of the Peasall sisters is the youngest ever Grammy nominee (and
winner) as one of the credited artists on the _[O Brother, Where Art Thou?
(soundtrack)](/wiki/O_Brother,_Where_Art_Thou%3F_\(soundtrack\) "O Brother,
Where Art Thou? \(soundtrack\)")_ in 2002.[4] Deleon Richards is the youngest
performer to receive an individual nomination, for Best Soul/Gospel
performance.[10]

Rank | Age | Artist  
---|---|---  
1 | 7 years | Leah Peasall  
2 | 8 years, 161 days | [Deleon Richards](/wiki/Deleon_Richards "Deleon Richards")  
3 | 9 years | Hannah Peasall  
4 | 12 years, 126 days | [Zac Hanson](/wiki/Hanson_\(band\)#Zac_Hanson "Hanson \(band\)")  
5 | 12 years, 155 days | [Joey Alexander](/wiki/Joey_Alexander "Joey Alexander")  
6 | 12 years, 199 days | [Michael Jackson](/wiki/Michael_Jackson "Michael Jackson")  
7 | 12 years, 273 days | [Billy Gilman](/wiki/Billy_Gilman "Billy Gilman")  
8 | 13 years | Sarah Peasall  
9 | 14 years, 45 days | [Chris "Daddy Mac" Smith](/wiki/Kris_Kross "Kris Kross")  
10 | 14 years, 182 days | [LeAnn Rimes](/wiki/LeAnn_Rimes "LeAnn Rimes")  
11 | 14 years, 197 days | [Chris "Mac Daddy" Kelly](/wiki/Chris_%22Mac_Daddy%22_Kelly "Chris "Mac Daddy" Kelly")  
12 | 14 years, 313 days | [Luis Miguel](/wiki/Luis_Miguel "Luis Miguel")  
13 | 14 years, 348 days | [Taylor Hanson](/wiki/Taylor_Hanson "Taylor Hanson")
